    Utility.Console.Colors
    The Colors class provides a collection of ANSI escape codes for text formatting, including colors and backgrounds, in supported terminal environments.

  • Constructor Details

      public Console()

  • Method Details

    • checkForANSI

      public static void checkForANSI()
      Checks if the console supports ANSI escape codes and updates the internal state.

      This method prompts the user to determine whether ANSI color codes are displayed correctly in their terminal. It displays a test message in green text and asks the user to confirm its appearance. The result of the user's input is stored in a class-level flag to indicate whether ANSI support is available.

      The check is performed only once during the runtime to avoid redundant prompts. Later calls to this method will not prompt the user again if the check has already been completed.

    • supportsANSICodes

      public static boolean supportsANSICodes()
      Determines whether the current console environment supports ANSI escape codes. This method relies on an internal class-level flag that tracks if ANSI codes can be displayed in the terminal. The flag is updated based on user confirmation during an initial check performed by the `checkForANSI` method.
      Returns:
      true if the console supports ANSI escape codes; false otherwise

    • getBoxWidth

      public static int getBoxWidth()
      Retrieves the width of the box used for console-based text formatting or layout.
      Returns:
      the width of the box as an integer

    • clear

      public static void clear()
      Clears the console window by printing 50 new lines. This method simulates clearing the console output by iterating a fixed number of times and printing empty lines.

    • getNumericalInput

      public static int getNumericalInput(int min, int max)
      Prompts the user to input a numerical value within the specified range. Continues to prompt until a valid input is provided.
      Parameters:
      min - the minimum acceptable value (inclusive)
      max - the maximum acceptable value (inclusive)
      Returns:
      the valid numerical input provided by the user

    • getNumericalInput

      public static int getNumericalInput(int min, int max, List<Integer> validValues, int offset)
      Prompts the user to input a numerical value within the specified range and checks its validity against a list of acceptable values with an applied offset. The user will be repeatedly prompted until a valid input is provided.
      Parameters:
      min - the minimum acceptable value (inclusive)
      max - the maximum acceptable value (inclusive)
      validValues - a list of integers representing valid values for input (after applying the offset)
      offset - an integer value added to the user's input before validating against validValues
      Returns:
      the valid numerical input provided by the user

    • getNumericalInput

      public static int getNumericalInput(int min, int max, List<Integer> validValues)
      Prompts the user to input a numerical value within a specified range and optionally checks against a list of valid values.
      Parameters:
      min - the minimum allowable value for the input (inclusive)
      max - the maximum allowable value for the input (inclusive)
      validValues - a list of valid integer values that the input must match; can be null or empty for no additional restrictions
      Returns:
      the numerical input provided by the user that satisfies the specified constraints

    • getStringInput

      public static String getStringInput()
      Prompts the user for string input via the console and returns the entered value. The method ensures that any residual input in the scanner's buffer is cleared before capturing the new input. It also provides a prompt symbol to indicate that user input is expected.
      Returns:
      the string entered by the user

    • askForUsername

      public static String askForUsername()
      Prompts the user to enter their username via the console. Displays a formatted message asking for the username and waits for user input.
      Returns:
      the username entered by the user as a string

    • askForWildColor

      public static Card.Colors askForWildColor()
      Prompts the user to select a wild card color from a predefined set of options (Red, Yellow, Green, Blue) and returns the chosen color. This method displays a menu of color choices, waits for numerical input within the valid range, and maps the input to its corresponding color. If an invalid or out-of-bounds input is provided, the method defaults to returning the Red color.
      Returns:
      the selected wildcard color as one of the enumerated values in Card.Colors

    • writeTUIBox

      public static void writeTUIBox(String[] innerTextSplit, boolean isBoxBelow, boolean isBoxAbove)
      Writes a text-based User Interface (TUI) box to the console, formatting the input text within a bordered box structure. The method optionally allows for connector-style linking with a box above or below the current box.
      Parameters:
      innerTextSplit - an array of strings, where each element represents a line of text to be displayed inside the box
      isBoxBelow - a boolean indicating whether the box has a connector at the bottom linking it to another box below
      isBoxAbove - a boolean indicating whether the box has a connector at the top linking it to another box above

    • writeTUIBox

      public static void writeTUIBox(String innerText, boolean isBoxBelow, boolean isBoxAbove)
      Writes a text-based User Interface (TUI) box to the console, formatting the input text within a bordered box structure. This method simplifies the process by accepting a single string as input, which is split into multiple lines for display within the box. The method also allows for optional connections to a box above or below the current box.
      Parameters:
      innerText - a semicolon-separated string where each segment represents a line of text to be displayed inside the box
      isBoxBelow - a boolean indicating whether the box has a connector at the bottom linking it to another box below
      isBoxAbove - a boolean indicating whether the box has a connector at the top linking it to another box above

    • repeatString

      public static String repeatString(String string, int numberOfRepeats)
      Repeats the given string a specified number of times. If the number of repeats is zero or negative, an empty string is returned.
      Parameters:
      string - the string to be repeated
      numberOfRepeats - the number of times the string should be repeated; must be a non-negative integer
      Returns:
      a new string containing the repeated input string the specified number of times, or an empty string if the number of repeats is zero or negative
